data.title: Impressionism and Post Impressionism
data.meta_description:
Impressionism was a 19th-century art movement that began in Paris in the 1860s.   The name is derived from the title of Monet's work, , Sunrise (Impression, soleil levant). Characteristics of Impressionist painting include visible brush strokes, open composition, emphasis on light in its changing qualities, ordinary subject matter, the inclusion of movement as a crucial element, and unusual visual angles.
	
	Post-Impressionism is the term coined in 1910 to describe the development of French art since Manet. Post-Impressionists extended Impressionism while rejecting its limitations: they continued using vivid colours, thick application of paint, distinctive brushstrokes and real-life subject matter, but they were more inclined to emphasize geometric forms, to distort form for expressive effect, and to use arbitrary colour.
	
	Neo-impressionism is a variation of impressionism which is commonly known as pointillism.  It is characterized by fragmented brush strokes and colors.
data.text:
Impressionism was a 19th-century art movement that began in Paris in the 1860s. The name is derived from the title of Monet's work, , Sunrise (Impression, soleil levant). Characteristics of Impressionist painting include visible brush strokes, open composition, emphasis on light in its changing qualities, ordinary subject matter, the inclusion of movement as a crucial element, and unusual visual angles. Post-Impressionism is the term coined in 1910 to describe the development of French art since Manet. Post-Impressionists extended Impressionism while rejecting its limitations: they continued using vivid colours, thick application of paint, distinctive brushstrokes and real-life subject matter, but they were more inclined to emphasize geometric forms, to distort form for expressive effect, and to use arbitrary colour. Neo-impressionism is a variation of impressionism which is commonly known as pointillism. It is characterized by fragmented brush strokes and colors.
